Sample Outputs: o3

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 87.9
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Arthur Neegan shifted in the acceleration couch, the webbing rasping against his coverall. In front of him a thumb‑sized display, bolted to the bulkhead with four utilitarian screws, scrolled through diagnostics in lurid green letters: ATTITUDE 000.03° REACTION MASS 78 % CABIN pO₂ 20.8 kPa CREW: 3 + 1 GUEST Guest, Arthur thought sourly. More like conscript. Across the narrow aisle two Antares “diplomatic aides” sat erect, matte‑black carbines clipped to their pressure suits. Their orange pauldrons bore the stylised double star of the Antares Diplomatic Corps—an organisation legendary for having negotiated eighty‑seven treaties and fired the opening salvo in at least thirty of them. “Comfortable, Mister Neegan?” the senior aide asked. The tone was courteous; the eyes behind the visor impassive. “I’d be more comfortable in my own habitat with a mug of recycled coffee,” Arthur answered. “Where exactly are we going?” “Orbital platform T‑Seven. A representative is eager to speak with you.” “You people always eager,” he muttered, but the aide merely inclined his helmeted head. The thrusters fluttered to life. Mars fell away—a rust‑red disk veined with lights of the growing mining towns. Arthur’s personal claim lay somewhere down there, the lonely Quade Crater dig site where he’d planted a geologist’s flag two years ago. Beneath it—under a mere thirty metres of basalt—rested a filamentous seam of Azra ore that glowed eerily violet in ultraviolet lanterns and accelerated uranium decay by a factor of ten thousand. He had kept the find quiet; obviously not quiet enough. The shuttle clanged into docking clamps. Hatches irised. Synthetic air with a hint of ozone swept in. “After you,” the aide said, all politesse. Arthur floated through a short transfer tube into a cylindrical lounge. Plexi viewports revealed a pearly line-of-sight to Phobos, its surface freckled with military tracking dishes. Someone had gone to expense: brushed‑aluminium panels, a ring of mag‑boots for those who disliked free‑fall, a tea service clipped to a rail. Waiting in the centre, one boot magnetised to the deck, was a tall woman in a charcoal tunic. No weapons visible, which only meant they were hidden better. Her pale hair was drawn into a geometric bun, and a small pin on her collar showed the same Antares double‑star, rendered in platinum. “Arthur Neegan.” Her voice was low, precise. “I am Envoy Linnea Vor. Thank you for accepting our invitation.” Arthur caught the faintest twitch at the corner of her mouth—amusement at calling a compulsory escort an invitation. “I’m a reasonable man, Envoy Vor,” he said. “And reason tells me your men could have dragged me here tied to a cargo pallet. This way I still have my dignity.” “Precisely.” She gestured to a tethered chair opposite her own. “Shall we dispense with the customary refreshments and proceed to business?” Business. As if they were haggling over spare drill bits. Arthur strapped himself in. “I suppose you know about the vein.” “We know many things,” Vor replied. “What matters is what other people are guessing. At last count, five corporate consortia, two naval intelligence services, and the Martian Syndics Council suspect you sit on the largest Azra deposit ever recorded.” “Suspect isn’t confirm.” The Envoy’s fingers tapped a neat rhythm on a slate. “Mister Neegan, one of our probes lifted a sample from your refuse slag last week. The spectroscopic signature left no doubt. Congratulations.” Arthur’s stomach went hollow. He had been careful—he thought. Vor went on. “The moment word spreads, a dozen entities will try persuasion, then coercion. We intend to spare you that inconvenience.” “How altruistic.” “Altruism,” she said lightly, “is a luxury for stable epochs. This is not one. Azra is rewriting the strategic balance of the Spur. A gram can poison a fission warhead into early detonation, or halve an interstellar transit time. Whoever controls supply dictates the pace of colonisation—and of war.” Arthur exhaled. The lounge lighting seemed suddenly too bright. “So what does Antares want?” “An exclusive extraction contract. Our engineers keep the vein safe, you receive royalties beyond anything MarsCorp would pay, and you stay alive.” A simple sentence, yet it rang with subclauses you could drive a freighter through. “And if I decline?” “For someone of your technical profile, we project a ninety‑four percent mortality within six months.” Vor’s voice remained cordial. “Accidents happen in frontier mines. As you know.” “I’ve dodged cave‑ins before.” “You have not dodged orbital strikes.” Arthur absorbed that. No threat, merely an actuarial table recited aloud. He lifted his gaze to the viewport: the crescent of Mars, the labyrinthine channels of Valles Marineris stitched with city lights. All of it could vanish under a dust cloud if an Azra‑catalysed bomb went off down there. He swallowed. “What about the Colonial Charter?” he asked, grasping at legal straws. “Individual claim rights were guaranteed under Terran law.” “Terran law,” she echoed. “Earth is four light‑minutes and a political eternity away. On the frontier, enforceability is everything.” The aide at the hatch coughed. Vor raised a hand; the aide stepped back. “However,” she added, “we are not uninterested in appearances. There will be signatures, notarised holograms, escrow accounts in the Eurydice Bank on Ceres. You will seem a magnate rather than a hostage.” Seem. The word hung like frost in the air. Arthur rubbed his temple. He had grown up beneath the dull red sky of Mars, had dreamed of building cranes and pressure domes, not empires. Yet here he sat, a hinge on which empires might turn. “What about the others?” he asked quietly. “Terran Navy, the Jovian League—they’ll contest any unilateral claim.” “They may. That is why I am empowered to offer an additional inducement.” She produced a data cartridge no bigger than a thumbnail. The housing was cobalt blue, embossed with the double‑star. “Inside is a theoretical white paper on controlled Azra‑mediated decay throttling. In lay terms: a failsafe so your ore cannot be weaponised beyond a certain yield. You hand this to the Terrans at an open hearing, they applaud your civic virtue. Meanwhile production proceeds under Antares license. Balance of power preserved, public relations secured.” Arthur stared. “Why give me a knife whose handle points at your own throat?” “Because Antares relies on calculus, not superstition. A limited monopoly is preferable to a chaotic scramble. The other powers will accept stalemate if the alternative is annihilation.” “And if I publish the paper without signing your contract?” Vor shrugged. “Then we revert to the ninety‑four percent scenario, and the galaxy slides closer to chaos. Your choice, Mister Neegan. We would prefer you rich, alive, and moderately famous.” Silence stretched. Beyond the viewport, Phobos drifted like a skull. Finally Arthur said, “I want amendments. My own overseers on site. Independent auditors every quarter. And the first tranche of royalties into a Martian credit union, not Ceres.” Vor considered, then nodded once. “Acceptable. Though the auditors will, by necessity, be Antares‑approved.” “I’ll take what I can get,” Arthur said. “And I want written assurances no ordnance, orbital or otherwise, will be deployed within five hundred kilometres of Quade Crater.” She allowed herself a wisp of a smile. “Spoken like a man who intends to keep breathing. We have an agreement.” She extended a stylus. Arthur took it; his hand shook only a little as he pressed his thumbprint on the scrolling holo‑contract. The green letters flared gold: PROVISIONAL. Vor pocketed the stylus and floated to the hatch. “Prepare to disembark,” she told the aides. “Mister Neegan and I will return to the surface in the hour. There is much to organise.” Arthur unstrapped, feeling both heavier and lighter. He had just accepted a fortune and, perhaps, a lifetime of carefully curated captivity. Still, there were cracks in every wall, even diplomatic ones. And a miner knew how to widen cracks. “Mister Neegan,” Vor called, already drifting away. “Welcome to diplomacy.” He watched her vanish down the corridor. The little diagnostic screen above his couch still blinked green. SYSTEMS NOMINAL, it declared. Arthur wasn’t so sure.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures Asimov's style with its focus on political intrigue, technological implications, and dialogue-driven narrative. The author has created a tense negotiation scene that effectively conveys the high stakes of Arthur's discovery while building the larger world through conversation rather than exposition. The writing demonstrates strong command of sci-fi elements with technical details like "CABIN pO₂ 20.8 kPa" and concepts like "Azra-mediated decay throttling" that give it an authentic hard sci-fi feel. The retrofuturistic vibe comes through in details like "scrolled through diagnostics in lurid green letters" and the "thumb-sized display, bolted to the bulkhead with four utilitarian screws." Character-wise, Arthur is portrayed as a practical miner caught in political machinations beyond his experience but not beyond his intelligence. His reactions are believable for someone in his position. Envoy Vor is effectively characterized as coolly professional with subtle hints of ruthlessness beneath her diplomatic veneer. The dialogue is particularly strong, with the verbal sparring between Arthur and Vor revealing character and plot simultaneously. Lines like "Altruism is a luxury for stable epochs" efficiently communicate the political philosophy of the Antares Diplomatic Corps while characterizing Vor. The prose balances technical description with more poetic touches ("Phobos drifted like a skull") without becoming purple. Scene-setting is economical but effective, giving just enough detail to visualize the orbital platform while keeping focus on the conversation. The piece does an excellent job of hinting at larger stakes through dialogue rather than exposition. We learn about the political landscape, the importance of Azra, and the precarious balance of power through the negotiation itself. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Some of the technical jargon occasionally feels slightly forced, and a few metaphors ("a hinge on which empires might turn") verge on cliché. The ending, while appropriately ambiguous, could perhaps have a stronger hook to propel the reader into the next chapter. Overall, this is a highly successful piece that captures Asimov's style while telling an engaging story about political maneuvering in a well-realized future setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The safelight hums a low red glow over everything, turning the trays of developer and stop bath into shallow pools of blood. My boots stick to the rubber mat as I shift my weight, trying not to look as restless as I feel. I’m usually all swagger—cropped leather jacket, geometric liner so sharp it could slice film—but tonight my body language feels borrowed. Elliot stands across from me, shoulders curved inward like parentheses, humming some wordless melody while our prints float face‑down in the chemicals. I’ve been watching him all semester, pretending it’s academic interest: how does someone photograph negative space with that much tenderness? But the truth is, the minute he walked into class in a moth‑eaten lace shirt and steel‑toed boots spray‑painted matte black, I lost the plot. Nineteen, fresh out of whatever small town, carrying a thrift‑shop nu‑goth wardrobe and a library of obscure theory in his head. A softness I don’t know how to catalogue. The darkroom door thumps shut behind us, sealing out the hallway fluorescence. Inside, the hush feels conspiratorial. I stir the developer with the tongs, watching silver halides wake up on the paper. Elliot’s tune—something minor, lilting—threads through the chemical smell. “You always hum when you’re nervous,” I say, half‑teasing, half‑probing. He startles, cheeks already tinted red under the light. “I didn’t realize.” He stops, then almost apologizes with a shrug. “It’s… grounding.” Grounding. I file the word away. He rarely volunteers feelings; when he does, they’re lapidary, precise. We’ve been partnered for the final project—long‑exposure portraits, identity as palimpsest—and the department’s budget means sharing after‑hours darkroom slots. It’s the third night past midnight, and I’m learning him in small exposures: how he tests the enlarger focus three times even when it’s perfect, how he presses his knuckles to his mouth when he’s thinking, how the perfume of fixative clings to his hair like ghostwater. I flip our first print and slide it into the stop bath. Shadows halo his face, the long shutter making his outline misty, like he’s in the act of becoming. He leans over my shoulder, so close I feel his breath whisper through the silver hoops in my ear. “That’s the thing,” he murmurs. “I can’t tell if it’s me or just a draft version.” I want to quip—tell him everyone’s a beta build—but the joke tangles in my throat. Instead I ask, softer than I expected, “Draft of what?” He hesitates so long the timer buzzes. I move the print into the fixer, and only when the image locks permanent does he speak. “Of who I might be if… gender wasn’t a script someone else handed me.” The words drift out like smoke, fragile, immediately searching the air for permission to exist. My chest does that weird expand‑contract thing I get on roller coasters. I’m the take‑charge girl, the one who orders the drinks, decides whose place, whose hands go where. But Elliot’s vulnerability sits between us like an untouched negative: any careless light could ruin it. “Do you want to talk about it?” I ask, careful not to load the question with obligation. He nods, eyes fixed on the fixer tray. “I keep thinking about softness. How I want it on the outside, not hidden under cargo pants and raised voices. I try on blouses in thrift store dressing rooms and feel more honest than I ever do in a men’s section. But then I walk out and… the world snaps the picture before I’m ready.” I glance at his profile: kohl smudged almost imperceptibly at the corners, a silver ring nesting on every other finger like punctuation. The look isn’t exactly masculine or feminine; it’s a sentence still being diagrammed. And I want to protect the unfinished beauty of it the way I shield a fresh print from light leaks. “I’m listening,” I say, because that feels like the most radical thing I can offer. He finally meets my eyes. “Does it weird you out?” A laugh snorts out of me, too loud in the dark. “Weird is my operating system, El.” Then, more honestly, “I’m… figuring out how it intersects with me. I usually know what I’m attracted to. Defined edges. Guys who are capital‑M Men or women who are unapologetically femme. Your… in‑between is messing with my shortcuts.” He hides a smile behind the sleeve of his fishnet cardigan. “Sorry?” “Don’t be,” I say quickly. I tap the print with the tongs, watching water bead off the glossy surface. “It’s exhilarating. Terrifying. Like shooting with expired film—you don’t know what develops, but sometimes the colors are wild.” Silence drapes over us, not uncomfortable. I lay the print on the drying rack and reach for another sheet. My hand brushes his, and an electric something jumps skin to skin. My default would be to grab, stake a claim. Instead I pull back, letting him decide if contact continues. He surprises me by turning his palm upward, inviting. I slide my fingers into his, gentle as lowering paper into developer. His rings are cool against my calluses. “I used to think agency meant talking the loudest,” I confess. “Now I’m realizing it might mean stepping back so someone else can step forward.” He squeezes. “Maybe it’s a dance.” I raise an eyebrow. “You dance?” “Only alone in my apartment.” He flushes again. “Badly.” I grin. “We’ll add that to the project: blurry motion study.” The timer beeps for the next exposure. He releases my hand and positions a new sheet under the enlarger. I watch the red light halo his hair—dark, straight, almost blue where it catches the glow. His posture has uncoiled a little, like a flower tricked into dawn. “Can I ask something?” I say. “Sure.” “What name would you choose if the script was blank?” He exhales, long. “I’m not sure yet. Elliot fits, but… some days I try Elia, or just Elle.” He glances at me, gauging reaction. Something warm spills in my stomach. “They’re all gorgeous. Whatever you choose will look good on you.” I mean it. The possibilities feel like extra apertures opening inside my rib cage, letting in light I didn’t know was available. He steps to the side so I can adjust the focus ring. Our shoulders touch. He’s humming again—same minor key, but steadier. I count silently: one one‑thousand, two one‑thousand. At five I click the shutter, bathing the paper in inverted starlight. While it exposes, he speaks so softly I almost miss it over the ventilation fan. “I wonder if attraction changes when the person you’re interested in changes shape.” My pulse trips. “You mean… us?” A tentative nod. The question hovers: Do we label this before either of us finishes developing? I chew my lip. “I think attraction is less like a snapshot, more like a contact sheet. You keep discovering frames you didn’t know you shot.” He laughs, a quick bright thing that makes me want to kiss him. I don’t. I force my hands to stay on the enlarger column, letting him have the next move. The timer dings. He lifts the exposed sheet with tongs, lowers it into developer. The image swivels up from blankness: his figure doubled, a slow shutter ghost overlaying a sharper outline. One foot in shadow, one in light. He watches it form, mesmerized, then looks at me. “I feel like that. Two versions overlapping.” My voice comes out hoarse. “Would it help if someone believed both are real?” “Yes,” he whispers, almost a question. “Then I do.” I clear my throat. “Whatever timeline you’re on, I’m game to witness.” The print reaches completion, tones settling. He fishes it out, water dripping from the corner like melted garnet. “Dani?” “Yeah?” He sets the print on the blotter, then, with a self‑possessed slowness I didn’t know he had, cups my jaw. His thumb strokes the edge where my bold liner meets skin, like he’s noting contrast. “Can I—” “Agency, remember?” I tease, heart stampeding. He smiles, eyes dark and sure. “May I kiss you?” I nod, surprised by the shiver of being asked instead of taking. His lips taste of developer and wintergreen gum. The kiss is soft, exploratory, leaving room for edits. When we part, he rests his forehead against mine. The ventilation fan hums, his earlier melody woven in. Outside the darkroom, morning is probably bleeding into the sky, but in here everything’s still red and possible. We return to the trays, shoulder to shoulder, the silence now companionable. I realize I’m not giving up control; I’m learning a new exposure triangle: vulnerability, agency, curiosity. And tonight, under the safelight, both of us are still developing—grainy, unpredictable, beautifully incomplete—but for the first time, I don’t want the image to be finished too quickly.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her attraction to Elliot during their darkroom sessions. The piece effectively establishes the setting of the darkroom with its "red glow" creating an intimate, confessional atmosphere as requested in the prompt. The author skillfully weaves photography terminology throughout the narrative, creating an authentic backdrop for these art students. The characterization of Dani is strong and consistent with the prompt's description - she's portrayed as assertive and bold, with her "cropped leather jacket" and "geometric liner so sharp it could slice film." Her internal struggle between her usual take-charge attitude and her desire to give Elliot agency is well-developed. The narrative effectively shows her growth as she realizes "agency might mean stepping back so someone else can step forward." Elliot's character is also well-rendered, with his "moth-eaten lace shirt," "steel-toed boots," and "nu-goth wardrobe" matching the prompt's description. His vulnerability as he shares his gender questioning feels authentic and is handled with sensitivity. The chemistry between the characters develops naturally through their interactions in the darkroom. Their conversations have a tender awkwardness that feels genuine, particularly when Elliot shares his gender questioning and when they discuss their mutual attraction. The dialogue is strong, revealing character and advancing the narrative without feeling forced. The prose is elegant and evocative, with photography serving as both setting and metaphor. Descriptions like "shadows halo his face, the long shutter making his outline misty, like he's in the act of becoming" effectively blend the technical aspects of photography with Elliot's journey of self-discovery. The author uses the darkroom process as a metaphor for identity development throughout the piece. The narrative successfully explores Dani's complex attraction as requested in the prompt. Her internal conflict is well-articulated: "I'm the take-charge girl, the one who orders the drinks, decides whose place, whose hands go where. But Elliot's vulnerability sits between us like an untouched negative: any careless light could ruin it." Her confusion about what this means for her own identity is also addressed when she admits, "I usually know what I'm attracted to. Defined edges. Guys who are capital-M Men or women who are unapologetically femme. Your... in-between is messing with my shortcuts." The ending feels earned and consistent with the characters' development. It doesn't rush to a conclusion but leaves them "still developing—grainy, unpredictable, beautifully incomplete," which fits the photography theme and the exploratory nature of their relationship. The piece does occasionally veer into slightly purple prose with metaphors that feel a bit strained, such as "the perfume of fixative clings to his hair like ghostwater." However, these moments are relatively few and don't significantly detract from the overall quality of the writing. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling narrative with well-developed characters and an evocative setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
1. 10:05 a.m. — Fontana di Trevi The Vespa skids, tires shrieking against smooth marble. A scarlet helmet jerks up; espresso‑dark eyes lock on a tall man in linen sleeves who is frozen mid‑stride, guidebook obscuring half his face. A jet of water arcs behind them, tourists gasp. “Ma che fai, signore? Vuoi morire oggi?” the rider barks. Ben lowers the book, cheeks flushing. “I—terribly sorry. I didn’t see—well, you were rather… fast.” She cuts the engine, props the bike with a flick of her boot. “Fast is relative. You were a stone.” She gestures to the congested piazza. “Move or be art.” Ben gulps. “Er—yes. Quite right.” Then, with awkward generosity: “Are you hurt?” She laughs, a bright metallic sound. “Io? Bulletproof.” She notices the guidebook’s dog‑eared page. “You reading about the fountain while standing in front of it? How very British.” He smiles, helpless. “Occupational hazard. I study seventeenth‑century urban space. Seeing what the text leaves out.” “Sei un professore?” Her brows lift with theatrical admiration. “Fancy. Alessandra,” she says, extending a gloved hand still vibrating from adrenaline. “Ben Whitaker.” They shake; her grip is warm, mischievous. Something imperceptible transfers—later he’ll realize it’s his pen that vanishes from his breast pocket. “Since you almost died,” Alessandra announces, “I owe you a tour.” “Oh, you don’t—” “Shh. Academic research. Get on.” She scoots forward. The seat is warm; basil and gasoline swirl in his nostrils. Before courtesy can stop him, he’s straddling the Vespa, knees touching the leather of her jacket. “Hold tight, professore.” He does. 2. 11:30 a.m. — Via dei Coronari They rocket through medieval alleys. Alessandra darts between delivery vans, shouting greetings and obscene jokes. Ben’s knuckles whiten around the seat bar, yet a delighted laugh keeps escaping him. At a red light she flicks up her visor. “Hungry yet?” “Starved.” She points to a bakery window. “The best maritozzo in Rome. But no paying. Watch.” Inside, the clerk waves, charmed already. Alessandra chats, distracts, compliments the clerk’s tattoo. Two cream‑stuffed pastries later, they stroll out. Ben notices no money changes hands. “Did you just—” “We borrowed sweetness from the city.” She licks cream off her thumb. “Pay it back with a wish.” She tosses a coin—the one she’d plucked from a German tourist’s change dish—into a tiny street shrine. Ben should object. Instead he devours the maritozzo, sugar dusting his chin. Freedom tastes like orange zest and wrongdoing. 3. 1:00 p.m. — Testaccio Market The Vespa coughs to a stop beside a corrugated hangar. Inside, tripe steams, and fishmongers sing insults across aisles. Alessandra orders two panini alla pajata. Ben eyes the offal. “Is it… intest—” “Cow kindergarten, yes.” She winks. “When in Rome.” He bites, expecting horror, finds peppery bliss. Sauce drips onto his notebook; she dabs it with the edge of her scarf—an elaborate silk thing of indeterminate origin that he’s fairly sure was knotted on a mannequin five minutes ago. Suddenly a voice behind them: “Ale, ancora in giro a rubare cuori?” A broad‑shouldered man in a butcher’s apron appears. Marco, an old acquaintance. “Ciao, bello.” She claps his shoulder. Marco’s eyes settle on Ben. To him, sotto voce: “Occhio. She’ll steal the saints off altars.” He mimics pocketing something, then grins and returns to his stall. Ben chuckles nervously. Alessandra’s smile doesn’t deny a thing. 4. 3:20 p.m. — The Tiber Embankment They sit on crumbling travertine, legs dangling over slow‑green water. Sun turns the surface to hammered gold. “So,” Alessandra says, skimming a pebble, “why leave safe little libraries?” “I wanted… perspective.” He hesitates, then admits, “Also exhaustion. I spend years footnoting other people’s passions.” He studies her profile: wind‑tangled hair, a faint scar by her lip. “You seem to manufacture passion hourly.” She shrugs. “I chase motion. Standing still is… dangerous.” While they talk, her fingers toy with something in her lap. Only when she flicks it beneath him does he realize it’s a wallet—tourist’s, bulging with euros and AmEx. His pulse spikes. “You can’t—” She snaps her fingers; the wallet shoots back into her palm, a magician’s flourish. “Relax, professore. I return most of it.” A pause. “Sometimes.” He should stand, report her. Instead he laughs, dizzy. “You are chaos incarnate.” “Grazie.” 5. 5:45 p.m. — Abandoned Cinema Paradiso, Trastevere Rusty chains bar double doors. Alessandra produces a bobby pin. “Need to stretch your academic legs.” Click. They step into cool darkness. Dust motes swirl like ghosts of applause. She leads him up a staircase to the roof. Rome unfurls—domes, terraces, satellite dishes, laundry flags. Wind whips pages of Ben’s guidebook. Alessandra takes it, tears out the Trevi section, folds it into a plane, and launches it over tiled rooftops. “Empirical revision,” she declares. Ben watches the paper soar, something unbuttoning inside him. “You’re rewriting my syllabus.” Their faces drift close in the violet light. For a breath, silence. She edges back first. “Don’t fall in love with me, English.” It’s half challenge, half plea. He answers, soft: “Impossible request.” 6. 8:10 p.m. — Gianicolo Hill Scootered out, they walk the final incline. Street musicians play “Volare,” slightly off‑key. City lights glitter; swifts dive like sparks. Alessandra produces a small object, presses it into Ben’s hand. His missing pen. “You lifted it at the fountain.” He’s amused, impressed. “I return what matters.” A rare seriousness shadows her. “Pens write futures, sì?” Before he can reply, she leans and grazes his cheek with her lips—swift as her pickpocketing. Electricity pools behind his eyes. “Domani?” he whispers. “Maybe.” She steps back, helmet under her arm, silhouette framed by the last rose of sunlight. “Find me where Romans break the rules.” With a roar, the Vespa carries her downhill, tail‑light shrinking among the pines. Ben stands alone, guidebook lighter by several pages, heart heavier by something nameless. He pats his pockets, half expecting more theft, finds instead a folded parking ticket tucked in his shirt. On it, scrawled in red lipstick: Stolen moments are the only ones that count. –A (An address. Midnight.) He laughs into the Roman night, utterly undone and already following.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of a contemporary romance set in Rome through a series of interconnected scenes. The structure works effectively, with time stamps and locations creating a clear progression through a single day. The writing demonstrates considerable skill in establishing the contrasting personalities of Alessandra and Ben while developing their chemistry. The characterization is particularly strong. Alessandra emerges as a vibrant, impulsive character whose kleptomania is subtly revealed through actions rather than exposition. Her "self-admitted troublemaker" nature comes through in her driving, her casual theft, and her boundary-pushing. Ben's transformation from flustered academic to someone willing to follow Alessandra into increasingly risky situations is handled with nuance, though it happens rather quickly. The prose is largely elegant, with vivid sensory details that immerse the reader in Rome: "basil and gasoline," "cream-stuffed pastries," "slow-green water." The author employs effective metaphors and similes that enhance rather than distract from the narrative. Occasionally, the writing becomes slightly overwrought ("Electricity pools behind his eyes"), but these moments are rare. Dialogue is crisp and character-revealing. Alessandra's mix of Italian phrases and direct English captures her personality well, while Ben's polite hesitations reflect his more reserved nature. Their exchanges feel natural and build tension effectively. The narrative successfully creates a sense of escalating adventure and growing attraction. The ending leaves an appropriate amount of ambiguity while suggesting continuation, with Alessandra's note providing a satisfying hook for what might come next. Some minor weaknesses include the somewhat rapid development of Ben's attraction and willingness to overlook Alessandra's criminal behavior. While his fascination is established, his ethical compromise happens with minimal internal conflict. Additionally, while Rome is vividly depicted, a few more specific cultural details might have enhanced the setting further. Overall, this is a skillfully crafted piece that successfully establishes compelling characters, creates genuine chemistry between them, and uses Rome as more than just a backdrop. The writing is confident and controlled, with a strong sense of voice and pacing. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 80.2
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I polish the same thumb‑sized swirl on the bartop, slow circles in the lacquer while the asteroid station’s hum settles into my bones. Copper‑blue fairy lights run along the ceiling struts; the holo‑jukebox murmurs a jazz riff nobody’s bothered to skip for three straight nights. Miners argue about ore percentages at Table Five, a merchant couple negotiate a prenup at the booth under the hydro‑vine, and I keep my rag moving so I don’t have to think about why I still don’t trust quiet evenings. The airlock door sighs. In comes trouble. Four lavender‑gray tentacles of hair flop over a lean face. Dark coat shredded at the sleeve. Eyes like cracked opals. The stranger plants themself on the stool in front of my endlessly wiped spot. “Vega whisky, neat,” they say, voice frayed as static. “Better make that a double.” “Rough transit?” I flip a glass upright. “Rough… everything.” They rub a fingertip across a welt on their cheekbone. “Name’s Kaolin, if that matters.” “Names only matter if someone shouts ’em.” I pour the amber liquor, double measure. “House rule: you break the glass, you buy the glass.” “Fair.” They knock back half the whisky, cough once, then press the rim to their forehead like it might fix something inside. “You run this place?” “Just tend it,” I answer, rag still circling. “Station’s called The Last Outpost because it’s farther from trouble. People come here to leave baggage in the hallway.” “Baggage follows,” Kaolin mutters, draining the rest. “Another.” I hesitate, glancing at the clock that claims it’s only third watch. “Double again?” “Triple if you’ve got compassion.” “Compassion comes in two‑ounce portions.” I pour. The holo‑jukebox glitches, scattering brass notes like moth wings. I keep my voice low. “What’s chasing you?” Kaolin’s tentacles twitch. “Depends who you ask.” “Fine, I’m asking you.” “Then… an employer who thinks I stole from them. A syndicate who thinks I owe them. And a Union patrol who thinks I’m dead.” “Dead folks don’t drink,” I say. “They do if the paperwork’s sloppy.” From the dice table, one of the pixid miners—half a meter tall, glittering wings—calls, “Hey, Nets, we’re dry!” “Minute,” I shout back, but I don’t move. My rag keeps polishing the same swirl, spreading a darker ring where condensation gathered. “You carrying anything hot?” Kaolin pats their coat. Something metallic clinks. “Define ‘hot.’” “Explosive, infectious, or valuable enough to get my bar spaced.” “Only the last one.” “Joy.” I slide a bowl of soaked bairn‑berries toward them. “Eat, or the whisky’ll punch back.” Kaolin plucks a berry, studies it like it might be wired. “You always play nurse?” “Only to patients who tip.” I nod at the register. They flip a credchip onto the counter. Platinum. The kind that screams attention. “Keep that under the bar before someone prints a reason to rob you,” I hiss. Kaolin blinks, then palms the chip again. “Thought you’d appreciate prompt payment.” “I appreciate quiet payment.” My rag’s circle widens, anxiety making loops bigger. “Anyone else know you’re here?” “Not yet.” As if summoned, the airlock hisses again. Two station security officers stride in—sleek vacuum armor, gold faceplates reflecting every neon speck. Behind them stalks a woman in slate‑black leathers, coat studded with silver hexes: bounty hunter. I know her—Captain Dalva Reeve, Union‑licensed, zero humor. I tuck the whisky bottle under the shelf, heart ticking faster. Dalva’s boots clack toward the counter. “Evening, Nets.” “Captain.” I force a grin. “Long flight?” “Short warrant.” She plants both hands on my bar, visor polarizing clear so I can see the scar crossing her lip. “Looking for someone. Zivesian hybrid, tentacled dreads, possibly injured.” I glance at Kaolin. They stare into their glass, perfectly still. I keep wiping. Same spot, tighter circles. “We get hybrids all the time, Captain. You’ll need to narrow.” “One answers to Kaolin Vesh.” Dalva leans in. “Seen ’em?” The miners quiet. The jukebox hisses. My rag squeaks over wood. I sigh. “Color of credits?” Dalva slides a holopad across. “Legal, Union‑sealed. Ten thousand for a location ping.” Kaolin’s knuckles whiten around the glass. I breathe through my teeth, stare at the swirl I’ve polished half a millimeter deeper. “What’s the charge?” “Industrial sabotage, terrorism, theft of restricted tech, conspiracy to—” Kaolin interrupts, voice shaking: “Self‑defense, whistleblowing, theft of my own research, and conspiracy to stay alive.” Dalva’s gaze flips to them. “Well, that was easy.” She gestures; the security duo unholster shock‑binders. The entire bar watches. No one moves—yet. I slide the rag into my belt, palms down on the counter. “Captain, station reg subsection fourteen: no apprehensions inside civilian bars without owner consent. House rights.” Dalva arches a brow. “Owner’s not here.” “Proxy authority.” I tap the keychip around my neck. “You know the law.” “I also know this warrant outranks a liquor license.” “It doesn’t outrank hospitality statute.” I keep my tone velvet, but inside I’m ice. “Give them one drink’s grace. They finish, they step outside with you. Everyone keeps their dignity.” The miners murmur approval. The pixids flutter onto a light fixture for a better view. Dalva straightens. “Five minutes. Then I drag them out.” “Four,” I say, because I can’t help winning something. She retreats to a corner, armor clicking. I meet Kaolin’s eyes. “You’ve got four minutes to convince me you’re worth a mess.” “Mess follows me,” they whisper. “So does morning. Talk.” Kaolin inhales. “I designed a micro‑jump coil for Gehenna Corp. They planned to retrofit asteroid miners—good, right? Found out they’re installing it in skip‑bombs instead. Planet‑crackers.” “Corp deniability,” I mutter. “I stole the prototype data to leak it. But the coil’s on this station, Nets, in Dock C—scheduled to depart on the freighter Marrow Tide at dawn. They get it past the rim, millions die.” I glance at Dalva. She chats with the security pair, bored. “You sure?” Kaolin slips a small prism from their coat. It glows blue where my bar lights hit it. “Core crystal. Without it, the coil won’t fire.” “So you crippled it.” “For now. They have backups. I need a ship and thirty hours to broadcast proof to the Union open‑net, or Dalva hands me over to Gehenna, who erases me and slaps a ribbon on the bomb.” I fold the rag, hands suddenly sweaty. “I don’t do hero work.” “I’m paying.” They offer the platinum credchip again. “And I’m begging.” I stare at the chip, then at the spot I’ve wiped raw. My reflection swims in it—someone who ran from her own past crimes and swore never to pick a side again. From the corner, Dalva calls, “Three minutes, Nets.” I swallow. “Even if I help, you won’t make it past the blockade alone.” “Got friends?” Kaolin asks. I scan the bar. The miners owe me tabs, the pixids love fireworks, and the jukebox still glitches on the same jazz riff. Maybe that’s a rhythm I can work with. “Maybe I do,” I say. “Two minutes!” Dalva’s visor snaps opaque. Kaolin leans closer. “Decision time.” I pick up their empty glass, start polishing the rim with my rag—same tight circles—my brain whirring faster than the station’s air recyclers. Conflict settles into the room like smoke, and I’m breathing it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere while establishing clear conflict. The author has crafted a first-person, present-tense narrative as requested, with Nettle (Nets) as the bartender protagonist at The Last Outpost. The dialogue comprises roughly 60% of the text, meeting that requirement. The writing establishes a strong sense of place through sensory details like "copper-blue fairy lights," the "holo-jukebox murmurs," and the "asteroid station's hum." The bar setting feels lived-in and authentic, with background characters like miners, merchants, and pixids creating texture. Character-wise, Nets is well-developed through her actions and internal thoughts. Her habit of polishing the same spot on the bar reveals her anxiety, and her past is hinted at without being fully exposed. Kaolin, the stranger, is introduced with visual details that suggest distress, and their predicament unfolds naturally through dialogue. Captain Dalva serves as a compelling antagonist with specific traits like her "scar crossing her lip" and professional demeanor. The conflict is effectively established: Kaolin has stolen research to prevent a corporation from using it for weapons, and now faces multiple pursuers. The stakes are high (millions of lives), and Nets is pulled into a moral dilemma that connects to her own mysterious past. The chapter ends without resolution, with Nets contemplating whether to help Kaolin. However, there are some weaknesses. The worldbuilding, while colorful, occasionally relies on sci-fi tropes without fully developing them. Some dialogue exchanges feel slightly mechanical, particularly when characters are explaining plot points. The prose occasionally becomes purple, with metaphors like "scattering brass notes like moth wings" that don't quite land. The pacing is generally strong, though the transition from Kaolin's arrival to the bounty hunter's entrance feels somewhat rushed. The countdown timer (four minutes, three minutes, etc.) creates tension but feels slightly contrived as a plot device. Overall, this is a solid piece of cozy sci-fi that establishes an interesting world, compelling characters, and a conflict with both personal and larger stakes. It successfully leaves the reader wanting to know what happens next. + Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I smell the river before I see it—thick, swamp‑sweet, like rotting fruit and hot metal. The morning sun hasn’t burned off the mist yet, and everything looks ghosted: the iron balconies, the torn posters for jazz nights, the street whose name I can’t pronounce. My right backpack strap keeps sliding off my shoulder, so I hitch it back up and mutter at it like it’s to blame for every lousy thing that happened back home. Back home. Two words that already feel counterfeit. I pick a direction—south, because I’m already Gone South, might as well keep the bit running—and start walking. Last night’s truck ride ended at a gas station on Claiborne. The driver, a wiry guy who kept calling me “buddy,” wished me luck like I was off to summer camp instead of exile. I slept maybe forty minutes on a plastic bench outside a twenty‑four‑hour pharmacy, hugging my pack like a life preserver. My ribs still remember the shape of the armrest. Today’s mission: find a bathroom, food, and a corner of the universe where I’m not someone’s problem. A kid about my age sprawls on the opposite bench under the St. Louis Street sign. Leather jacket in July—full anarchist chic—and a black eye fading to yellow. He’s plucking at a busted pair of earbuds, trying to un‑snarl a knot the size of a mouse. He glances up, catches me staring. “You got a light?” I shake my head. “Don’t smoke.” “Neither do I,” he says, grins, and tucks an unlit cigarette behind his ear. “Name’s Cricket.” Cricket, like the bug. Great. “Taylor,” I say, shifting my bag so the strap quits sawing my collarbone. “You from around here?” “Nah. Blew in from Atlanta three weeks back. Thought I’d find music, magic, I dunno.” He shrugs. “Mostly found heat rash and cops.” We eye each other, two houseplants yanked from pots and shoved on the same cracked windowsill. Some instinct tells me he’s playing the part of “harmless,” but I don’t have the luxury to demand background checks. “I need coffee,” I say, because it’s true and because it’s safer than saying I need practically everything. Cricket’s grin widens. “Lucky you. I know a place that forgets to lock the back patio door before they open.” He hops up, slings a shredded messenger bag over one shoulder. “Don’t look so shocked. I’ll even pay. Got cash from busking last night.” The sensible portion of my brain—Mom called it my “cold storage conscience”—screams Stranger danger! But that same conscience also told me not to transition, not to run, not to do half the things that kept me alive so far, so I flick it off like a gnat. “Lead the way,” I say. We duck through an alley that smells like bleach and beer, then emerge onto Frenchmen Street. Music coils out of doorways, even at 9 a.m. A trumpet coughs scales; a drummer argues with a cymbal. I feel like Dorothy stepping into Technicolor, except my slippers are busted Converse and the wizard doesn’t take walk‑ins. Cricket slips behind a café, pushes on a warped wooden gate. It creaks open. Inside, ceiling fans churn lazy circles over mismatched tables. No customers yet. A barista with silver hair pierces us with librarian eyes. “We’re not open.” Cricket pats his pocket. “I’ve got legit money, Ms. Rose. Promise.” She sighs like this is an old argument, then waves us toward the counter. He orders two iced coffees and a pair of kolaches that look like happiness stuffed with sausage. He pays. She even smiles at me—like, a real human smile, not the tourist‑tolerance variety. We plant ourselves at a corner table. Air‑conditioning prickles my sweaty arms, and for a second I consider living right here forever. Cricket raises his cup. “To runaways and rewrites.” I tap mine against his. “Rewrites,” I echo, tasting sweet cold caffeine and the possibility of not crashing for at least six hours. “So,” he says, leaning back, “what’s your headline?” “My what?” “Front‑page story. Why’d you bail on wherever you’re from?” I run my thumb over the condensation on my cup. Words pile up behind my teeth—trans, disaster, Dad’s face folding in on itself—but none tumble out. “Family drama,” I say instead. “Small‑town crap. You?” He tilts his head, studying the ceiling fan. “Had a stepdad who believed you can smack the gay out of someone. Turns out you can’t, but he sure clocked overtime trying.” I flinch. It feels like reading my own diary only with the pages scrambled. “You okay?” “Better than him,” he says lightly, then adds, softer, “I’m still here.” Silence hums between us. Outside, a trolley bell clangs. My brain chews on the parallel lines of our escape stories, the way they almost overlap but not quite. The slipping strap picks this moment to bail again. I yank it back up, frustrated. Cricket’s gaze lands on the rainbow pin safety‑clipped to the backpack flap. “You one of us?” The question is so gentle it cracks me right open. My eyes sting. “Yeah,” I whisper. “Trans, actually.” Cricket nods like I just told him my favorite kind of pizza. Relief floods me, hot and embarrassing. I gulp coffee to hide it. We talk in half‑sentences. Favorite bands (he: Against Me!; me: old Fall Out Boy, un‑ironic), worst meals eaten on the road, the difference between being alone and being lonely. I find myself laughing, real laughter that shakes cobwebs loose. Around noon Ms. Rose ushers us out with two day‑old croissants “for the road.” The sun slams into us like an oven door. We wander toward Jackson Square, navigating clumps of tourists and tarot readers. A street performer in feathers croons “House of the Rising Sun.” Cricket drops a quarter in her case. I spot a public fountain and bee‑line for it, splashing my face. When I look up, Cricket’s talking to a lanky guy in sunglasses. The guy hands Cricket a folded piece of paper. My gut knots. Cricket rejoins me, stuffes the paper in his jacket. “Friend of mine,” he says too fast. “Just a flyer for a gig tonight.” “Lemme see?” He hesitates, then shrugs and hands it over. It’s not a flyer. It’s an address scrawled in block letters: Warehouse 19, Bywater. Ask for Ghost. Underneath: NO COPS. “Some band practice?” I ask, keeping my voice casual. “Sorta.” He scratches the back of his neck. “Look, there’s this squat. Safe place, usually. Food, mattresses, no questions. Thought you might want in.” Alarm bells jangle, but the idea of a roof, even a questionable one, tempts me like nothing else. “You trust these people?” Cricket’s gaze skips sideways. “Trust is expensive. I’ve got coupons.” Not comforting. My phone—miraculously still at 32 percent—buzzes. Mom: Where are you? Pls just text. I stare until the screen times out. My throat tightens. Cricket notices. “You can call if you want. I won’t eavesdrop.” I shake my head. “Not ready.” Maybe never. We drift along the river. A steamboat whistle startles pigeons into the sky. I rehearse worst‑case scenarios: the warehouse is a trap; Ghost is an axe murderer; cops raid and drag us to juvenile; Mom sobs on the phone, “Why did you do this to us, to yourself?” Then I picture another night on a bus bench hugging my bruised ribs. The backpack strap slips again, final straw style. I curse and retighten it. Cricket reaches over, adjusts the buckle, and for a heartbeat his fingers steady my shoulder. “Tonight,” he says, “you won’t need that bag as a pillow.” Trust is expensive, I think. But being alive costs something too, and I’m already in debt. “Okay,” I say. “Warehouse 19.” We walk on, the sun dropping westward, our shadows stretching toward whatever comes next.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a teenage runaway navigating a new environment after coming out as trans. The first-person narration creates immediacy and intimacy, allowing readers to experience Taylor's internal conflict, vulnerability, and cautious hope. The writing excels at establishing a strong sense of place. New Orleans comes alive through sensory details: "thick, swamp-sweet, like rotting fruit and hot metal," the morning mist, iron balconies, and music "coiling out of doorways." These details ground the narrative in a specific setting while reflecting Taylor's emotional state. Character development is handled with subtlety. Taylor's voice feels authentic—a mix of teenage cynicism, vulnerability, and dark humor. The internal monologue effectively conveys their conflicting emotions without becoming melodramatic. Cricket serves as an interesting foil—someone with parallel experiences but different coping mechanisms. Their interaction feels natural, with the gradual building of tentative trust. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character through what's said and unsaid. Lines like "Trust is expensive. I've got coupons" efficiently communicate Cricket's worldview and history. The conversation about identity is handled with restraint—Cricket's casual acceptance of Taylor's disclosure ("You one of us?") is powerful precisely because it's understated. The pacing works well, covering Taylor's first day in New Orleans while building tension about what might happen next. The piece avoids the trap of resolving too much too quickly. Instead, it ends with Taylor making a choice that feels both risky and necessary, leaving readers curious about the consequences. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some metaphors, while evocative, occasionally feel slightly overworked ("like Dorothy stepping into Technicolor, except my slippers are busted Converse and the wizard doesn't take walk-ins"). The piece also introduces several potential plot threads (the mysterious warehouse, Taylor's family situation) that naturally remain unresolved given the word count constraints. Overall, this is a compelling chapter that establishes character, setting, and conflict while maintaining emotional authenticity. It avoids both sentimentality and excessive darkness, instead finding a nuanced middle ground that feels true to the complexity of Taylor's situation. + Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The dawn was the colour of weak tea that had already been used to polish boots. Midas peered over the parapet of the half‑collapsed shopping mall he called “home base” and decided—again—that no apocalypse worth its salt should start this early in the morning. Chewy, the animo‑tronic koala, dangled from his shoulder, glass‑button eyes whirring into focus. A small red light behind the fur flickered once, twice, then produced a cheery jingle: “FuzzyCare™—Hug the Future Today!” Midas winced. The last thing he needed was nostalgia advertising at sunrise. “Right,” he muttered. “Mission briefing. Agenda item one: procure breakfast that isn’t eight years past its best‑by date. Agenda item two: find a battery so you’ll stop blurting commercial archaeology at me.” Chewy’s speaker crackled. “Buy bulk, save more!” “That’s… possibly relevant,” Midas conceded, “but we’ll start with breakfast.” He consulted the hand‑drawn map he’d recreated from tattered tourist brochures. A pre‑collapse warehouse, rumoured to contain “non‑perishable miracle food bars,” lay three miles east. Midas reckoned that anything called a miracle must have had at least a fifty‑fifty chance of still being vaguely edible, which was better odds than the canned eel incident. “Route?” he asked the koala, not because the koala was good with navigation—Chewy’s compass function had been replaced by a looped animation of a dancing eucalyptus leaf—but because talking to someone, even plush polyester, reduced the loneliness. “Scan‑scan‑scanning… Fabulous savings await!” “Close enough.” They set off. The morning remained unseasonably breezy, which in post‑collapse terms meant “things might only try to eat us twice before lunch.” Midas skirted the busted asphalt, steering around wind‑tossed billboards declaring HOLIDAY MEGA‑SALE—ALL MUST GO!* *They did. Dramatically. By mid‑morning they reached the highway interchange, a tangled pretzel of rebar and regret. A sign announced EXIT 7B: FULFILMENT CENTRE →, though most of the arrow had rusted away, pointing more toward a suspicious ravine than anything promising. “You first,” Midas told Chewy, placing him on a jutting slab. The koala waddled forward with the steady confidence of a drunk toddler. A loose pebble skittered, the slab shifted, and the entire freeway remnant sighed. Midas followed because gravity enjoys company. They clambered down what was left of an off‑ramp and immediately startled a herd of goat‑things—ordinary goats once, now sporting an extra horn each and the surly expression of creatures who’d expected better from evolution. The largest snorted, steam puffing from flared nostrils. Chewy chose that moment to broadcast at maximum volume: “Try the NEW Ultra‑Crisp Protein Flakes—Powered by SCIENCE!” The goats considered this, decided science was overrated, and charged. Midas ran. Chewy bounced against his chest like a caffeinated metronome. They vaulted a guardrail, plunged into a drainage culvert, and splashed along until the goats’ hoofbeats faded. When Midas finally stopped, his boots oozed suspiciously. “Great. Wet socks and no breakfast.” Chewy’s motion sensor detected the stink of despair and attempted comfort. “Batteries sold separately!” “Story of my life.” They emerged beside the warehouse—a windowless rectangle of corrugated metal that looked precisely like the kind of place a supervillain would grow mushrooms made of spite. The main door was padlocked, but apocalypse doors, like apocalypse plans, seldom survive first contact with a determined idiot. Midas produced a crowbar, applied leverage, and discovered an alarm wire he hadn’t noticed. Somewhere inside, a klaxon coughed, tried to find its dignity, and roared. “INTRUDER ALERT!” hollered a tinny speaker. “SECURITY DRONES ACTIVATING!” Midas swore. Chewy, never one to miss a trend, chimed, “For savings that FLY at you!” A servo whined. Out shot a spherical drone whose original job—safely delivering plush toys to children—had been repurposed into pelting trespassers with high‑velocity foam blocks. They hurt surprisingly much. Midas ducked; Chewy, lacking knees, took a direct hit and tumbled. The commotion dislodged a stack of shelving. Boxes spilled. Something black and tarry—industrial molasses, possibly, or mood—splashed over the floor. Midas skated, arms windmilling, and crashed into an open crate. He surfaced clutching a silver foil package the size of a brick: MIRACLE FOOD BAR, CLASSIC MEAT‑LOAF FLAVOUR. Success, technically. “Mission accomplished!” he yelled, precisely as the shelving behind him collapsed fully, revealing a row of dormant cleaning bots. They stared with the baleful LED eyes of machines that remembered what humans did to them on “casual Friday.” Their vacuum nozzles spun up. Midas bolted through the emergency exit, tripped the fire‑suppression sprinklers, and emerged soaked and foamy, still gripping his meat‑loaf miracle. Chewy followed, trailing bubbles like a vengeful bath toy. By now afternoon clouds rolled in, rumbling with the sullen promise of acid drizzle. Home base lay three miles west, which felt longer when you’d annoyed goats, drones, shelving, and possibly the concept of gravity. Halfway back, they ran into a bandit ambush: three figures in mismatched sports padding, wielding lacrosse sticks sharpened to an unsettling point. “Tribute,” the leader rasped. Midas offered a weak smile. “We accept all major credit cards?” Chewy, dangling, declared, “Now with twenty‑five percent MORE!” The bandits decided they would very much like twenty‑five percent more of whatever would stop the koala shouting. They advanced. Midas, still possessing the crowbar and an unlucky streak, raised the bar.* *An improvement on his usual performance, which tended to trip over it. The ensuing scuffle could only be described by someone fond of the word “undignified.” In the end the bandits left with two foam drone welts each and considerably less respect for the profession. Midas limped away with a cracked shin guard and an additional miracle bar he’d filched during the melee—spinach soufflé flavour, presumably for sinners. Twilight settled like a giant exhausted cat. Rain hissed. Lightning silhouetted the mall’s crumbling façade: letters long fallen so that it now read ALL‑MART. “Home sweet, ambiguously labelled home,” Midas sighed. They crept inside, wary of the local raccoon collective (who imposed a toll of shiny objects). Midas bribed them with a reflective road sign he’d pried earlier. The raccoons, pleased, did not steal his boots this time—a considerable improvement over Tuesday. At last they reached their hideout atop Housewares, a nest of blankets, shopping trolleys, and one solar lantern that thought it was a firefly. Midas collapsed. His clothes reeked of goat fear, industrial foam, and dubious meat‑loaf. He produced the miracle bars, ceremoniously tore open the meat‑loaf brick, and sniffed. It smelled of nostalgia filtered through despair. They both took a bite. It tasted worse. Chewy conducted a rapid‑fire flavor analysis: “Mmm! Just like Motherboard used to make!” “Shut up,” Midas groaned, finishing the brick out of spite for reality itself. He checked himself: new bruises blooming, one eyebrow singed, but alive. The day’s haul: two miracle bars (one consumed, one regrettably spinach), a cracked shin guard, and a fresh supply of stories no one asked for. Chewy powered down to standby, the red light blinking morse‑code comfort: YOU LIVED ANOTHER DAY. Outside, thunder rumbled, perhaps applauding, perhaps laughing. Midas pulled a tarp over the hole in the ceiling and looked at his still humming companion. “Well, buddy,” he murmured, “tomorrow we try again.” Chewy’s eyes snapped open one last time before sleep mode. “Collect the whole set!” Midas snorted. “Working on it.” He drifted off to the faint clicking of distant drones resetting, goats bleating angrily at rain, and the world, as always, falling sideways—but only the usual amount. End tally: socks destroyed (2), dignity located (0), kalories acquired (approximately), apocalypse survived (1, provisionally). Worse for wear, but at least better than dead, which—as Midas reminded himself—was terribly unproductive. He dreamed of a time before slogans, before miracle meat‑loaf, when koalas remained sensibly non‑promotional. What a curious fantasy. Morning, inevitably, would judge him for it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its clever wordplay, absurdist humor, and footnotes. The post-technological collapse world is vividly rendered through details like the "half-collapsed shopping mall," "busted asphalt," and "tangled pretzel of rebar and regret." The author effectively uses Pratchett-esque similes and metaphors, such as "dawn was the colour of weak tea that had already been used to polish boots" and "twilight settled like a giant exhausted cat." The characters are well-established. Midas embodies the hapless protagonist archetype with his knack for finding trouble, while Chewy provides comic relief through his malfunctioning advertising slogans. Their relationship feels authentic despite Chewy being an inanimate object, capturing the loneliness of the apocalypse. The mission structure follows the prompt perfectly: the pair deliberate their predicament (finding breakfast), embark on a mission that goes sideways (encounters with goat-things, security drones, and bandits), and return to home base worse for wear (bruised, singed, with questionable food). The prose maintains a consistent tone throughout, balancing dry humor with genuine peril. The author skillfully employs footnotes in Pratchett's style to deliver additional punchlines. The dialogue, though limited due to Chewy's restricted vocabulary, serves the story well and establishes character. Where the piece could improve is in its emotional depth. While entertaining, it doesn't quite reach the philosophical undercurrents that often lurk beneath Pratchett's humor. The ending, while satisfactory, doesn't deliver a particularly profound insight or character revelation. The story occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when describing the bandits and the raccoon collective. These elements could have been more fully developed through action and dialogue rather than exposition. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that successfully emulates Pratchett's style while creating a unique post-apocalyptic world. The humor lands consistently, the characters are engaging, and the narrative flows well from beginning to end.
