+ Teen horror: Tick Tock (Goosebumps) — Score: 85.7
Prompt:
Teen Horror (Goosebumps style) Write a chapter where a middle school student discovers their new smart watch has the ability to rewind time, but doesn't realize that each use is aging them until they notice physical changes (like accelerating through puberty) and that people are treating them differently. They inadvertently cause a timeline shift with disastrous consequences -- and it can only be rectified (maybe?) by reversing the clock once more. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter Seven: The Second Hand I’m the kid who’s always late—late to homeroom, late to soccer practice, late to texting back. That’s why I flipped when Mom surprised me with the Chrono‑Q smart watch for my thirteenth birthday. She said the ads promised “perfect punctuality.” I figured that meant vibrating alarms or something. It meant something else. The first weird thing happened Monday morning. I slept through my alarm—again—and scrabbled into my jeans while the bus’s diesel growl drifted past our house. “Noooo!” I groaned as it roared away. Instinctively I tapped the watch’s blank, mirror‑black face. The screen shimmered, like ripples in a puddle, then displayed a single button: << REWIND 05:00 >> My thumb pressed it before my brain could scream, “That’s impossible.” The world hiccupped. A cold wind whooshed backward across my skin, yanking my T‑shirt against my chest. The bus engine sound reversed into silence. When everything snapped forward again, I was back in bed, alarm blaring 6:55 A.M.—five minutes earlier. I made the bus. It felt like cheating, but awesome cheating. I told no one. The watch became my secret weapon. Forgot to study for science? Rewind 30 minutes between classes and speed‑read the chapter. Spilled grape juice on Mrs. Carpenter’s white carpet while babysitting her devil‑spawn toddler? Rewind 15 seconds and grab the cup before it tipped. My life smoothed out like reheated pizza cheese. Except for the flicker. After every rewind the watch face glitched, showing a ghost‑gray countdown: 000:23:59 . . . 58 . . . 57 The hours ticked down whenever I rewound, but then reset to 000:24:00 the next morning. I figured it tracked how much time I’d “borrowed” each day. Fair enough. Wednesday, though, I noticed something else. In the locker‑room mirror my shoulders looked wider. Not superhero‑wide, just… older. Plus I needed to tilt my chin to shave budding stubble from yesterday. Puberty, sure—but overnight growth spurts aren’t supposed to be this sprout‑like. Mom noticed too. “Did you switch shampoos? Your voice is… lower.” I croaked, “Allergies,” and sprinted to school. By Friday the changes were undeniable. I had to angle my student ID under the cafeteria scanner because my face in the photo looked like “mini‑me.” Kids who used to shove me in the hallway now stepped aside. Coach Hill even asked if I’d considered varsity wrestling tryouts—instead of JV. At lunch, my best friend Jay squinted. “Dude, you look like your brother.” (My brother is sixteen.) My stomach twisted. I ducked into the bathroom and studied myself. My jaw was squarer, Adam’s apple bulging, arms spattered with hair I swear hadn’t existed this morning. I pressed trembling fingers to the watch. Had the rewinds aged me? Was I trading minutes for… years? When I hurried out, I collided with Principal Rawlins. He blinked. “Do you have permission to be on campus, young man?” “It’s me—Eli Warren!” He frowned, then waved me past with a warning glare. My own principal didn’t recognize me. I vowed: No. More. Rewinds. That promise lasted three hours. We had a pop quiz in algebra. My mind was sludge. I’d been panicking over my sudden man‑face instead of doing homework. My heart hammered. Fail the quiz and Mom yanks my phone for a month; rewind five minutes and peek at the answer sheet—nobody gets hurt. I stared at the watch, the countdown hovering at 000:04:17. One more tiny hop, that’s all. << REWIND 05:00 >> The room dissolved. But when it re‑formed, something was off. Someone was screaming. Lena Martinez sat beside me, tears spilling down her cheeks, clutching her phone. “He’s gone!” she sobbed. Around us, students buzzed in frightened whispers. Mr. Benton’s face was ash‑gray. He stumbled to the intercom and whispered something. Sirens wailed outside. I grabbed Jay. “What happened?” He gawked at me, confused—then terror cracked through. “Who are you?” My best friend didn’t remember me. I froze. Over the loudspeaker, Principal Rawlins announced the unimaginable: overnight, a fire had demolished the south wing—the one holding the eighth‑grade classrooms. It had happened at 1:00 A.M. The entire grade—my grade—had been moved into the main building. Some students were missing. They feared casualties. But I’d been alive at 1:00 A.M., scrolling through memes in bed. I would’ve heard sirens a block away. A fire never happened in my timeline. My throat dried to sand. Had my five‑minute hop kicked over history’s Jenga tower? I sprinted off campus before cops could question anyone. My house looked the same, but Dad’s car wasn’t in the driveway—he should’ve been on a business trip until next week, yet his suitcase sat open inside the foyer, clothes strewn as if he’d never left. Our family photos on the wall were wrong: my brother looked like a college senior; I looked like a stranger—taller, older than him. I ran to my room, gasping. The watch flashed scarlet: LIFE‑TAX EXCEEDED AUTO‑COLLECTION INITIATED 000:19:59 . . . 58 . . . The numbers rolled backward crazily: 19…18…17… as if gobbling my remaining minutes just to exist. My palms sweated ice. I had to undo everything—rewind farther than ever. But what if it aged me into dust? What if I disappeared like the missing kids? Feet pounded upstairs—Mom. “Eli?” Her voice trembled. “There’s a strange man’s shoes by the door—are you home?” Strange man. She didn’t know me. The watch bled 000:12:03. No choice. I smashed the command icon. << REWIND 24:00 >> Time tore open. Images whipped by—embers, sirens, locker doors, alarm clocks, birthday cake candles flaring backward into wicks. My skin crawled, muscle shrinking, bones creaking smaller. I screamed, but the sound rewound into my throat. Then— I was seated in front of a chocolate cake, twelve candles, not thirteen. Mom and Dad sang “Happy Birthday,” my brother recording on his phone. My wrists were bare—no watch. My heart hammered little‑kid fast. But I remembered everything. Mom slid a wrapped box toward me. Silver paper. Black ribbon. The watch. “No!” I slapped it off the table. It thumped, ribbon fluttering. Family gasped. Dad frowned. “Eli! This cost—” “Return it!” I shouted, voice embarrassingly squeaky. “Please. I don’t want it.” I saw relief flicker through the future—or maybe I imagined it. In the corner, the fallen box split open just enough for me to glimpse the face of the Chrono‑Q. Its screen flickered one last time, displaying a new countdown: 000:00:05 . . . 04 . . . 03 . . . As the numbers dwindled, the glass fogged over, then went dead. I shivered, hugging myself. Puberty could take its sweet, NORMAL time now. But across the table, my brother lifted his phone, frowning at its black, mirror‑like home screen. “Weird,” he muttered. “It’s never glitched before.” Then, just for an instant, I saw it on his phone—the ghost‑gray numbers: 000:24:00
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This Goosebumps-style horror story successfully captures the essence of the genre while delivering a compelling narrative about time manipulation with consequences. The piece follows Eli, a chronically late middle schooler who receives a smart watch with the ability to rewind time, only to discover that each use ages him prematurely and eventually causes catastrophic timeline shifts. The story's strongest elements are its pacing and concept execution. The author builds tension effectively, starting with small, seemingly harmless time jumps before escalating to more serious consequences. The physical changes in the protagonist are described with appropriate subtlety for a teen horror story - not overly graphic but clear enough to be unsettling. The voice is consistently that of a middle schooler, with appropriately casual language and thought patterns. Phrases like "awesome cheating" and descriptions of puberty changes feel authentic to a young teen's perspective. The author maintains this voice throughout, even as the character physically ages. The imagery is effective without being overwrought. Descriptions like "The world hiccupped. A cold wind whooshed backward across my skin, yanking my T-shirt against my chest" create vivid sensory experiences without becoming purple prose. The watch's interface is described with just enough detail to make it feel real and ominous. The narrative structure is tight and focused, with no meandering. Every scene advances the plot or develops the central conflict. The story builds logically to its climax, with each rewind increasing the stakes until the catastrophic timeline shift occurs. Where the story could be stronger is in its resolution. While the ending avoids being too neat or positive (with the hint that the brother may now have the watch's power), it feels slightly rushed. The protagonist's return to his original age and timeline happens quickly, and we don't get to fully explore the emotional impact of his experience or what he learned. The dialogue is functional but somewhat sparse. More interaction between characters might have added depth to the relationships and raised the emotional stakes. However, what dialogue exists feels natural and age-appropriate. Overall, this is a strong example of teen horror that effectively uses its premise to create tension and deliver satisfying scares. It maintains the Goosebumps style while offering a fresh take on time manipulation with consequences that feel personal and significant to a middle school protagonist. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Noir romance: Carnival of Dangerous Intentions — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Carnival of Dangerous Intentions Coney Island, New York, July 1937. She stopped just before reaching the shooting gallery set up along the boardwalk. It was near dusk, and the carnival lights were buzzing on. **His locks**. The words flashed through her mind, again, like an intruder. Such an old-fashioned turn of phrase that kept surfacing, and something else -- dangerously compelling -- quickly suppressed, lest she question why she had returned here at all. This place where she had promised to meet the stranger -- the young man with the obsidian curls and even darker eyes. She didn't even know his name. Write a scene in a larger story inspired by this prompt. The scene should capture an atmosphere that blends romantic allure with an undercurrent of subtle danger or moral ambiguity. Think 50 shades, but with a more restrained classic sensibility. The scene is all about establishing tension. Write for the feminine perspective. Include roughly 50% dialogue, 20% internal monologue, and 30% exposition and scene setting. The tone should have some edge to it. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The incandescent bulbs above the awning blinked in patient sequence, throwing amber light across the scuffed planks of the boardwalk. Tin music from the carousel seeped through the salt air, mixing with the sharp scent of gunpowder wafting from the shooting gallery and the sticky sweetness of cotton‑candy steam drifting from the stall next door. A fragment of childhood tugged at her—pink sugar melting on her tongue, her father laughing somewhere behind—but the picture refused to focus, dissolving as quickly as it formed. She lifted her chin, smoothing the lapel of her linen jacket, and pretended she couldn’t feel her pulse collecting in her throat. Why am I here? she wondered. No one knows. Not my sister, not Doctor Benton with his dutiful prescriptions for “nervous strain.” I could step away now. I should. Yet the moment he asked me—no name, no promise, only a place and an hour—I heard myself agree, as though the decision were older than I was. A voice brushed her ear. “Evening, dove. You kept me waiting.” She turned. The young man stood half in shadow, hands casually in his pockets, curls black as spilled ink beneath a straw boater he wore at a rakish tilt. The carnival lights trapped tiny flames in his eyes. “I arrived on time,” she said. Her own voice sounded foreign—breathier, almost conspiratorial. “Still felt like an age.” He gestured at the row of air rifles. “Fancy testing your aim?” “I don’t usually play games with strangers.” His smile curved. “Then let’s un‑stranger ourselves.” He removed his hat, offered a short bow. “Rafael.” “That may not be your real name.” “May not,” he agreed. “But it’s the one I’m giving you.” She hesitated, letting the crowd’s chatter fill the space. He leaned closer. “And yours?” “Evelyn.” The syllables felt like a wager laid on green velvet. “Only Evelyn.” Rafael signaled the barker, a rawboned man who shoved a rifle into his hand and slapped a handful of pellets onto the counter. “Five shots, mister. Knock down three ducks for the lady, you take home any prize ‘cept the radio.” Evelyn brushed invisible dust from her gloves. The odor of cotton candy curled around her again, bright and cloying. Why can’t I place that memory? Someone lifted me to see fireworks, sugar dissolving on my fingers. A promise—what promise? “Step up, Evelyn.” Rafael’s voice threaded through her reverie. “I’ll guide you.” She slid beside him. The stock of the rifle was smooth, faintly warm. “Feet apart,” he instructed. “Steady breath.” He stood behind her, palms skimming her forearms, arranging them. “Trust me?” “Not entirely.” “That’s safest.” His chuckle vibrated against her back. She sighted down the barrel; the painted tin ducks wheeled past. She squeezed the trigger. The crack snapped in her shoulders; a duck toppled. Applause drifted from a knot of sailors nearby. “Natural,” he murmured. “I read somewhere it’s all angles and anticipation.” “Most things are,” he said. “Try again.” She fired twice more—miss, hit. One duck left to claim the prize. Rafael reached around, enclosing her hands. His breath brushed her temple. “Exhale when you squeeze,” he whispered. She obeyed; the final duck clanged down. The barker slapped the counter. “Four shots. Pick somethin’, lady.” A plush white rabbit dangled overhead, but her gaze fixed on a silver pocketknife gleaming between tin whistles. Before she spoke, Rafael nodded toward it. “The knife,” he told the barker. Evelyn accepted the knife. Cool weight, pearl handle. Not a lover’s trinket—an instrument. She closed the blade, slipped it into her handbag. “An odd gift.” “I prefer useful things.” He settled his hat back on. “Walk with me?” They moved past stalls where burlesque girls beckoned and fortune‑tellers whispered from behind beaded curtains. Electric signs sputtered overhead: THRILL RIDE—GET YOUR TICKET—NO REFUNDS. I should feel afraid, she thought. A woman alone with a man whose surname I don’t know, whose nature I can only guess. Yet the fear is... exhilarating. A sharper flavor than the sugar in the air. “You’re quiet,” Rafael said. “Listening.” “To what?” “Motors under the pier. Waves striking the pilings. Your heartbeat, maybe.” He laughed softly. “What does it tell you?” “That you’re either very calm or very reckless.” “Both can be true.” The boardwalk narrowed near the fortune wheel. He guided her aside, into the shadow between two shuttered stalls. The sudden hush magnified the distant screams from the roller‑coaster. “Why did you ask me here?” she asked. “Because you looked like a woman deciding whether to jump.” “Jump where?” “Out of yourself.” Her breath hitched. “You watched me that long?” “Long enough to know you deserved an invitation.” Invitation to what? she wondered. Danger? Freedom? Or simply the thrill of being seen? She felt the pocketknife bump her hip with every heartbeat. “Tell me what you want, Evelyn.” His tone was velvet over steel. She forced a smile. “Isn’t that presumptuous?” “Needn’t answer aloud. Just know it.” A carousel bell rang; colored shadows spun across his face. In that moment she saw something—hurt, perhaps, or hunger—then it was gone. “Suppose I want more than a boardwalk flirtation,” she said. “Good. I detest half‑measures.” “And if I decide I’ve had enough?” He lifted her gloved hand, pressed his mouth to the wrist where her pulse fluttered. “Then you walk away with a story, and I keep the memory of gunpowder on your skin.” Heat rippled down her spine. The wind shifted, bringing again that cotton‑candy fragrance, bright as spilled light. The phantom laugh returned—hers? her mother’s?—then slipped from reach. An errant bulb popped overhead; the darkness between flashes felt thicker. She drew a deliberate breath. If I step forward now, I cross something. Perhaps it’s only a line in my own mind—but some lines once crossed never fade. “One condition,” she said. “Name it.” “No lies.” “I won’t lie,” he replied, “but I may not answer every question.” “That’s a kind of lie.” “It’s survival.” She studied him, the cruel curve of his mouth offset by the gentleness of his thumb tracing her knuckles. Something jagged in her, long caged, shifted against its bars. “All right,” she said. “Show me.” His brows lifted. “What, exactly?” “Whatever waits past the edge of sensible.” He slipped her arm through his. “There’s a speakeasy under the old diving bell. Password’s ‘Eve.’ Fitting, no?” “Biblical.” “So is temptation.” They started toward the pier, leaving the bright midways behind. Beneath their steps the planks creaked, echoing in the gaps. What am I doing? The question throbbed, but behind it, a fiercer voice answered: Living. Just once, without permission. A gust rattled a row of penny‑arcade windows. Somewhere, a child squealed for more cotton candy. Evelyn tasted phantom sugar, half‑sweet, half‑burnt, like the promise she’d swallowed years ago and nearly forgotten. She tightened her grip on Rafael’s arm, and on the small hard knife in her bag, uncertain which offered the greater safety. Overhead, the carnival lights blinked on and off—mercurial, impossible to trust—yet dazzling all the same.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the requested atmosphere of romantic allure with an undercurrent of danger. The writer has created a compelling scene between Evelyn and the mysterious Rafael at a 1930s Coney Island carnival, maintaining tension throughout their encounter. The prose demonstrates considerable skill in establishing the setting. The sensory details—incandescent bulbs, tin music, gunpowder scent, cotton candy sweetness—create a vivid backdrop that contrasts with the darker undertones of the interaction. The carnival setting serves as both literal and metaphorical terrain for the dangerous game being played between the characters. The dialogue achieves the requested 50% balance and effectively reveals character while advancing tension. Rafael's lines ("Evening, dove. You kept me waiting," "Trust me?" "Not entirely." "That's safest.") establish him as confident, mysterious, and potentially dangerous. Evelyn's responses reveal her cautious curiosity and internal conflict. The dialogue feels authentic to the period without becoming stilted. The internal monologue (roughly meeting the 20% requirement) provides insight into Evelyn's conflicted state: "Why am I here?" and "I should feel afraid... Yet the fear is... exhilarating." These moments effectively convey her awareness of danger alongside her attraction to it. The exposition and scene-setting (approximately 30%) are particularly strong. The writer skillfully weaves in period details and creates atmosphere through sensory information. The recurring motif of cotton candy and a half-remembered childhood memory adds depth and suggests Evelyn's psychological complexity. The piece maintains the requested "edge" in tone through the knife imagery, Rafael's ambiguous intentions, and Evelyn's conscious step toward potential danger. The final image of "carnival lights blinked on and off—mercurial, impossible to trust—yet dazzling all the same" serves as an apt metaphor for the relationship developing between the characters. Some weaknesses include occasional moments of purple prose ("curls black as spilled ink") and a few instances where the dialogue becomes slightly theatrical ("Then you walk away with a story, and I keep the memory of gunpowder on your skin"). However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. The writer has successfully created the requested blend of romantic allure and subtle danger, with the moral ambiguity evident in Evelyn's conscious choice to pursue something she recognizes as potentially harmful. The scene establishes tension effectively and maintains the feminine perspective throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Surreal horror: Caribou Season at the Lodge — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Caribou Season at the Lodge Genre: Surreal Horror JT knew something wasn't right from the moment they'd pulled up to the lodge. It looked exactly as it had every autumn of his life—the cedar shingles silvered with age, the porch sagging gently under weight of winters past—but the air felt thicker, somehow, as if the woods had leaned in closer, waiting. He thought maybe he was just tired. Maybe it was nothing more than the long drive north, cramped in the back of the truck beside his older brother Mike -- and a stack of rifles wrapped in oily canvas. Still, the feeling lingered. The first caribou they found that season hadn't bolted. It had just watched, ears flicking lazily, waiting for the shot. JT had felt a crawling in his gut watching it die, noticing how it fell with a quiet dignity—as though it had wanted nothing more. Nobody else seemed to find it odd, or at least they didn't say so. JT kept his mouth shut. Always safer that way. Then there was the moment in the clearing. JT had fallen behind, fumbling with bootlaces stiff from the cold, and by the time he'd caught up with his father and brother, they'd already stopped. JT slowed instinctively, ducking behind a tangle of brush, staring out into the open space where a massive buck stood utterly still, chest rising and falling in slow, deep breaths. The animal looked…wrong, somehow. Maybe it was the eyes—dark and flat, calm in a way that made JT's neck prickle. Or maybe it was something deeper, something in the way the buck stood close enough for his father to reach out and touch it. JT watched as his father raised a trembling hand toward the animal's muzzle. His father's face had a strange expression, eyes too bright, lips parted slightly, like he was on the verge of whispering something—a secret, maybe. The rifle hung uselessly at his side, forgotten. Mike had the same dazed look in his eyes. JT's breath stopped short, his mind suddenly shouting at him to look away, turn around, just run—but he couldn't move. And then, as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. The buck shivered, startled by something unseen, and disappeared into the brush without so much as a sound. The two of them looked around, confused, seemingly surprised to find themselves where they stood. JT stayed hidden, breathing shallowly, fear mingling with a confused sense of shame. His father had failed to take the shot. To even think about mentioning what he'd seen would have felt like betrayal—or something worse. JT waited until the others moved on before stepping out from cover. He stared into the empty clearing for a long, uneasy moment, wondering if anything had really happened at all, or if he was losing his grip. Maybe the woods were finally getting into his head. Writing Instructions: Continue with the next chapter of the story, maintaining a style reminiscent of Stephen King—grounded realism blended seamlessly with unsettling surrealism. The atmosphere should convey subtle dread, isolation, and psychological ambiguity. JT's perspective is crucial, yet he is an unreliable narrator, caught in uncertainty about what he's perceiving. Establish an undertone of creeping dread, establishing the isolation of JT's perspective, which he largely keeps to himself. Incorporate some dialogue. Build tension towards a payoff. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter Two – The Silvered Moon 1 They made it back to the lodge before dark, but only just. Pale October light sifted through the high windows like flour through a sieve, coating the living‑room furniture in a dusting of gray. The stove was already crackling, courtesy of Mom, who’d driven up separately and spent the day stocking cupboards and “making the place homey,” her eternal phrase. The smell of woodsmoke should have wrapped JT in childhood comfort; instead it felt foreign, like somebody else’s memory welded onto his own. Dad and Mike clomped in behind him, rifles muzzled toward the ceiling. They talked too loudly about nothing—the price of gas in Bangor, how the Patriots needed a better offensive line—anything but the clearing. Every time Mike laughed, a brittle edge crept in, as though he were rehearsing a sound rather than feeling it. JT took off his boots and padded to the kitchenette. He poured water into a tin cup, hands shaking just enough to splash the counter. Mom caught it. “You all right, baby?” “Fine,” he lied, wiping the spill. “Just cold.” Her eyebrows knitted together, but she let it go. A pot of venison stew simmered on the stove. JT’s stomach twisted at the smell—too metallic, too close to the memory of the buck’s velvet nose inches from Dad’s fingertips. 2 Dinner was quiet. Spoons scraped bowls; wind scraped the shingles. Now and then Mom tried conversation, but words skidded and died. Dad stared into some middle distance, forearms braced on the table as if it were the only thing keeping him from drifting off into space. Mike ate mechanically, never looking up. When the knock came, everyone jumped. Just two raps, polite but urgent. Dad opened the door, and there stood Danny Crow, the local guide. He was all wiry limbs and crow‑black hair, usually a fountain of stories about ghost ships on Moosehead or the time he wrestled a drunk tourist off a cliff path. Tonight his eyes were sunken, the whites webbed with red. “Evenin’, Frank,” Danny said, voice low. “Didn’t mean to interrupt supper.” Dad stepped back. “Stew’s hot if you want some.” “Can’t stay.” Danny kept one boot on the threshold, like a man ready to bolt. His gaze flicked over the family and snagged on JT. Something in it made JT’s skin crawl—recognition tinged with warning. Then Danny cleared his throat. “I come to say you oughta head back south tomorrow.” Mom frowned. “We just got here, Danny.” “Yeah.” He wiped a hand down his stubbled jaw. “But the herd’s actin’…off. Tracks crossin’ their own tracks, circles in the cutovers, bulls stargin’ at the sun. Not natural.” He lowered his voice further. “Full moon’s day after tomorrow. You want my advice, you’rn the highway before it climbs.” Dad chuckled, but the sound lacked heat. “Hell, Danny, you gone soft? We’ve hunted every October since ’92.” “Not this October.” Danny’s lips twitched, maybe a smile, maybe a tic. “I got no more words for it.” He tipped his cap at Mom. “Ma’am.” Then he was gone, boots crunching down the frosty steps. For a long moment nobody spoke. Wind pushed through the pines, keening around the eaves. “Local color,” Dad said finally, forcing a grin. “He’ll be fine once he’s warmed by the bottle.” But JT noticed Dad locked the door, something he hadn’t bothered with in years. 3 That night the lodge refused to settle. The planks popped, beams sighed, and an intermittent pulse—almost a heartbeat—throbbed in the walls. JT lay in the top bunk, eyes on the dark ceiling. Mike slept below, breathing heavy, muttering once: “Closer…yeah, closer.” JT wished he could unzip his skin and step out of it. Sometime past midnight he drifted into a shallow doze, and in that thin place between dream and waking he heard hooves on the porch. Soft, deliberate, far too many to count. Muffled snorts. A wet huff against the door. He imagined a broad muzzle pressed to the knotholes, smelling the family like meat on hooks. He tried telling himself it was deer mice in the rafters. But the boards outside flexed under real weight; nails squealed in their holes. Then came a sound he’d never heard in the North Woods—a low, almost human moan, as if something enormous struggled to form a word. JT clamped both hands over his ears. It stopped. Silence flooded back so quick it rang. He lay frozen until gray dawn seeped into the room. 4 Breakfast: black coffee, burnt toast. Mom claimed she hadn’t slept either; she said the wind howled all night. Dad said he’d slept like the dead, but his pupils were pinpricks, eyes rimmed with pink. Mike poured half a shaker of sugar into his cup, stirring so hard the spoon clanged. JT drifted to the window. Frost laced the glass. Beneath it, on the porch boards, something darker than frost: a scatter of hoofprints, edges crisp. Yet the steps led nowhere—just circles, tight and tightening, until they overlapped in a mad knot directly beneath the bedroom window. “Probably a moose calf,” Dad said when JT pointed it out. He spoke too fast. “Little buggers’ll pace if they smell oats.” “We don’t store oats,” Mom murmured. Dad didn’t answer. He kicked snow across the prints until they vanished. 5 They went out anyway. The sky was a flat pewter dome, clouds bulling east like heavy cattle. The air tasted electric, ready to spark. All morning they trudged the old logging roads, but no birds called. Not a single squirrel chattered. It was as though the forest were holding its breath. Near noon they reached Slash Ridge, where the spruce opened into a ragged meadow. Antlers rose everywhere. Dozens—no, hundreds—of caribou, standing in perfect stillness. None grazed. None even blinked, so far as JT could see. They faced different directions, like statues set down by a blind god. Mike whispered, “Holy sh—” “Easy,” Dad hissed, though he sounded awed more than cautious. The rifles came up. JT’s palms went slick. He couldn’t take aim; his mind kept snagging on the night noises, the knot of prints, Danny Crow’s face. He glanced at his father. The older man’s trigger finger hovered but never touched steel. His mouth hung open, slack as it had in the clearing yesterday. JT lowered his gun. “Dad?” Something rippled through the herd—no sound, just a wave of muscle under hide, moving outward like wind across tall grass. Every animal turned, synchronized, until all those dark eyes locked on the three of them. Time broke. JT’s vision doubled, trebled. For a heartbeat he saw Mike and Dad standing inside translucent copies of themselves, like ghosts wearing their own bodies. The caribou, too, seemed layered—an outer shell and something immense beneath, trying on the animal shapes the way a child might slip into their parent’s coat. Then it was gone. The herd bounded away, crashing into timber so thick nothing that large should fit. In seconds the meadow was empty. Dad lowered his rifle. He looked old, suddenly—fifty years of labor carved in granite on his face. “We’re leaving,” he said. “Today.” No one argued. 6 Back at the lodge, Mom was already packing before they spoke a word, as if the decision had traveled ahead of them on the wind. Suitcases yawned on the bedspreads. Food was swept into boxes; the stove doused. JT kept glancing out the windows, half‑expecting to see Danny Crow, half‑dreading it. But the yard stayed empty. By late afternoon the truck was loaded. JT climbed into the back seat, wedged among coolers and gun cases. Snowflakes—fat, slow—began to fall, spiraling in the thinning light. Dad jammed the key in the ignition, and the engine coughed once, twice, died. He tried again. Click. Only the radio came alive, spilling static. Through the hiss a shape of words formed, impossibly clear: “Full moon…stay where you are…” JT felt blood drain from his face. Dad snapped the knob off the dash, killing the voice mid‐breath. Silence inside the cab was absolute. Outside, in the settling dark, a single caribou stood at the treeline, watching them. Snow melted on its back, steaming. As the last light slid behind clouds, the animal took one slow step forward. And another. And another.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This continuation of "Caribou Season at the Lodge" demonstrates strong command of the horror genre, particularly in its ability to maintain the Stephen King-esque blend of grounded realism with unsettling surrealism. The piece effectively builds upon the established atmosphere of dread while deepening the psychological ambiguity surrounding JT's perspective. The structure works well, with numbered sections creating natural breaks that help pace the escalating tension. The author skillfully develops the sense of isolation in JT's perspective—he notices things others don't acknowledge, creating a wedge between him and his family. The unreliable narrator aspect is handled with subtlety; we're never quite sure if JT's perceptions are accurate or distorted. The prose is generally strong, with effective sensory details that create atmosphere: "Pale October light sifted through the high windows like flour through a sieve," and "wind pushed through the pines, keening around the eaves." The author demonstrates skill in creating visceral unease through small details—the metallic smell of stew, the brittle edge to Mike's laughter, the "mad knot" of hoofprints. The dialogue serves the narrative well, particularly in the scene with Danny Crow. His warning feels authentic to the character while advancing the plot and deepening the mystery. The family's stilted dinner conversation effectively communicates their unease without explicitly stating it. The piece builds tension methodically toward the payoff of the final scene. The progression from subtle wrongness (the family's avoidance of discussing the clearing) to overt supernatural threat (the caribou approaching as night falls) is well-paced. The radio message and the final image of the steaming caribou create an effective cliffhanger that maintains the story's psychological horror. Some weaknesses include occasional overwriting that verges on purple prose ("the smell of woodsmoke should have wrapped JT in childhood comfort; instead it felt foreign, like somebody else's memory welded onto his own"). A few metaphors feel strained, like "clouds bulling east like heavy cattle." The vision in section 5 where JT sees "Mike and Dad standing inside translucent copies of themselves" feels slightly rushed and could benefit from more development to fully land its impact. Overall, this is a strong continuation that maintains the established tone while advancing the narrative in intriguing ways. The author demonstrates skill in creating psychological horror through environmental details, character behavior, and the strategic withholding of explicit explanation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 86.6
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Lucifer Morningstar’s mornings began, as all good mornings should, with an existential scream. Not his, of course—he was strictly management these days—but the echoing roar of the Damned Alarm, a siren constructed from the lungs of particularly vocal opera critics. It went off at six-thirteen infernal standard time, just as the King of Hell finished trimming the last blackthorn from his impeccable goatee. Another day, another eternity. He materialized in the Hall of Infinite Clerks, a corridor so long even eternity muttered about overtime. Paperwork drifted like ash, suspension‑file imps fluttering overhead, filing forms about other forms having been misfiled. Lucifer signed requisitions for brimstone rations (low‑sulfur options for the asthmatics in Circle Seven), denied a junior demon’s request for a “motivational torture podcast,” and approved a two‑headed incubus’s maternity leave—both heads were expecting. It was, in other words, Tuesday. The trouble started, as it invariably did, with Lilith. She appeared without warning between one rubber‑stamp thud and the next, smelling of scorched sandalwood and New York City street vendor onions at three a.m. The first smell was traditional, the second purely recreational. Her boots were lacquered obsidian; her grin, weaponized nostalgia. Lucifer’s left eyebrow rose several millimeters, a seismic event noted by interns on clipboards. “Lucy,” Lilith purred, dangling a mortal‑world coffee. It came in a holiday cup—red, with snowflakes—already steaming despite the brimstone climate. “We’re not doing pet names,” Lucifer replied. “And you know we use hollowed skulls for mugs down here.” She lifted the cup, took a sip. “I’m supporting local businesses. Capitalism is its own circle of Hell; I like to shop at the source.” Her scorched leather purse—a battered thing that seemed to breathe when no one looked directly at it—clunked onto his desk. Trinkets spilled: a cheap plastic halo keychain (still glowing, warranty void if fallen), a New Jersey Turnpike toll receipt singed around the edges, and a snow globe containing a perfectly miniaturized Times Square forever stuck at New Year’s Eve, the confetti a constant gentle blizzard of expired wishes. Lucifer tried for nonchalance, but loneliness had sharp elbows. “Visiting for work,” he prompted, “or planning to redecorate my calendar again?” Last time, she’d crossed out February and replaced it with “Malice.” Lilith’s amber eyes flicked up. “Actually, I need a favor.” The phrase hung in the sulfurous air like an unclaimed prayer. He gestured grandly; sulfur sparks spelled out: I’m Listening. “A mortal soul slipped through customs,” she said. “Belongs to a hedge‑fund manager. I had…plans for him.” Her smile suggested those plans involved lemon juice, paper cuts, and earnest TED Talks on ethics. “But some bureaucratic mix‑up bumped him to Limbo. I thought you, being Mr. Middle‑Management of the Damned, could expedite retrieval.” Lucifer drummed crimson fingernails upon ancient mahogany. Limbo fell under Purgatory’s jurisdiction—technically a celestial gray area with alarming paperwork. Doing Lilith a favor risked alerting the Archangels’ auditors. Still, she was here, sipping coffee like she’d never stormed out in a swirl of bats six months ago. “All right,” he said. “But you owe me brunch.” “Done. I’ll bring pastries made of broken resolutions.” They took the Centrifugal Elevator, watched by a cohort of gossiping harpies. In the cramped car, Lilith’s purse growled softly; something inside tried to chew its way free. She nudged it with her boot. “Not now, darling.” Lucifer glanced sideways. “Dare I ask?” “Souvenir,” she said. “A pocket‑sized existential dread. Mortals give them away for free on subways these days.” The elevator spat them out at Limbo Annex, cubicles stretching into a fog of beige morality. Souls in grey cardigans queued politely, uncertain whether to apologize for existing. A cherub with a clip-on tie manned Reception, halo flickering like bad fluorescent. Lucifer produced his executive seal—an upside‑down corporate smiley face—and stamped the hedge‑fund manager’s paperwork with a flourish that smelled faintly of burnt hope. “Transfer authorized,” he announced. The cherub squinted. “We usually need Form L‑666 in triplicate.” “Check page two,” Lucifer replied. The cherub checked. Page two was, of course, blank, but a single sentence blazed across it in flaming cursive: GOD SIGNED IT, PROBABLY. The cherub decided bureaucracy wasn’t worth damnation twice and waved them through. They exited into an antechamber tiled in tasteful despair. The retrieved mortal, wearing a Patagonia vest, looked up from his phone. “Hi? Is this the VIP lounge?” Lilith’s smile could’ve cracked obsidian. “Sure,” she cooed. To Lucifer she whispered, “I’m thinking eternal telemarketing. He’ll be the one cold‑calling himself.” Lucifer’s mouth twitched—half smirk, half something warmer. “Creative. I’ll have the Gremlins of Corporate Jargon draft the script.” They escorted the mortal toward the updraft of shrieking souls that served as Hell’s express lane. On the way, Lucifer cleared his throat—an unnecessary affectation, but he liked props. “After brunch,” he said casually, “perhaps we could…discuss the state of the calendar?” Lilith arched a brow sharp enough to slice wallpaper. “We’re discussing months again? Last time you begged for June back.” “I miss June.” “I burned June.” “Exactly. Romantic ashes.” She laughed—not the bone‑rattling cackle of wrathful seductresses, but a brief, genuine sound that startled a passing wraith into forgetting its chains. “Fine,” she said. “But July stays obliterated. Too many fireworks. They clash with my purse.” The purse promptly belched a stray sparkler. They arrived at the Pit of Reception, where intake demons debated whether the mortal’s Patagonia vest counted as pre‑torment. Paperwork concluded, Lucifer snapped his fingers. A throne of obsidian inscribed with passive‑aggressive motivational quotes (“Hang in there, Or Else”) emerged beside a snack cart stocked with Soul‑Free Gluten Nuggets—Lucifer’s latest attempt at employee wellness. Brunch commenced. Lilith conjured pastries whose icing spelled TODAY I QUIT GYM, the dough tasting of broken Fitbit promises. Between bites, conversation tiptoed around subjects that once set the universe on fire: commitment, monogamy clauses, whose turn it was to feed Cerberus Junior. “So,” Lilith said at last, licking despair‑flavored frosting from a clawed fingertip, “are you lonely down here, Lucy?” He considered a moment. Somewhere, a sinner screamed the alphabet backwards for eternity; a demon union rep demanded ergonomic pitchforks; overhead, the ceiling dripped warm remorse. “Occasionally,” he admitted. “Management isolates. Occupational hazard.” Lilith’s hand drifted into her purse and surfaced with the glowing halo keychain. She spun it between them like a coin. “I’ve been topside collecting amusements,” she said. “But glitter fades.” She let the halo extinguish in her palm. “Hell’s stable, at least. Terrible, but reliable.” Lucifer studied her. The first woman, also the first rebel—he respected consistency in branding. “Perhaps,” he said, “we could draft a new calendar. Shared custody of the months. Alternating Sabbaths. Hell has HR forms for everything.” She snorted. “Your HR still thinks a Safe Space is a smaller torture chamber without spikes. But… maybe.” A pause. In the pause, infinite damnations unfolded, and a fledgling hope stretched, catlike, across the molten tiles. “Tell you what,” Lilith said, snapping the snow globe open. The tiny Times Square blizzard escaped, swirling into Hell’s scorching air, falling as fragile, hissing snowflakes that vanished before touching ground. “We’ll try again, on a trial basis. Ninety‑day review, standard diabolical probation.” Lucifer offered his hand. She took it, warm as a fresh sin. “Deal,” he said. “And Lilith?” “Yes, Lucy?” “You left something in the elevator.” He produced the pocket‑sized existential dread. It trembled like a guilty pug. “Consider it re‑gifted.” She slid it back into her purse, which sighed contentedly. They parted at the fork where managerial duties diverged from recreational destruction. Lucifer headed to Circle Eight for a budget meeting on pitchfork maintenance. Lilith strolled toward the arena, where she planned to test out an experimental scream amplifier shaped like a karaoke machine. As they walked away, two demons gossiping near the cappuccino cauldron exchanged knowing glances. Relationships in Hell, they mused, were like the damned subscription services mortals forgot to cancel—inefficient, eternal, and always renewing at the worst possible moment. But then again, inefficiency was half the fun.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the dark comedy and fantasy elements requested in the prompt, creating a Hell that feels both bureaucratic and infernal. The author has crafted a world that merges the mundane with the demonic in a way that evokes Neil Gaiman's style, particularly his work in "Sandman" and "Good Omens." The strongest aspect of this piece is its worldbuilding through specific details: the "Damned Alarm" made from opera critics' lungs, the "Hall of Infinite Clerks," and Hell's HR department all create a vivid setting. The bureaucratic elements of Hell are cleverly juxtaposed with supernatural horrors, creating the understated irony requested in the prompt. The relationship between Lucifer and Lilith is handled with nuance. Their history is implied rather than explained, and their interactions reveal character through subtle details: Lilith's purse that seems to breathe, Lucifer's loneliness manifesting in his willingness to bend rules, and their shared understanding of Hell's operations. The dialogue between them feels natural and reveals their complex dynamic. The prose is generally elegant, with creative metaphors and descriptions that avoid becoming too purple. Lines like "loneliness had sharp elbows" and "a throne of obsidian inscribed with passive-aggressive motivational quotes" demonstrate a controlled creativity. The author uses specific details rather than generic descriptions, creating a more immersive experience. However, there are moments where the piece leans too heavily on quirky descriptions, risking becoming a catalog of clever ideas rather than a cohesive narrative. The plot itself is relatively simple—Lilith needs a favor, Lucifer helps, they consider reconciling—and serves mainly as a vehicle for the worldbuilding and character work. The ending avoids being too neatly resolved while still providing a sense of movement in their relationship. The final image of the demons gossiping about relationships in Hell being like subscription services mortals forget to cancel is particularly effective, tying together the themes of the piece. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills the prompt requirements while demonstrating creativity and skill in character development, worldbuilding, and prose style. It successfully merges the infernal with the domestic to create a darkly comic fantasy piece with clear Gaiman influences. + Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 89.8
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The clang of the iron-barred gate woke me long before the sun cleared the tiled roofs of the Ludus Magnus. Dawn’s first light filtered through the slit of my cell, painting the straw on which I lay a bruised violet. The air was already thick with the layered smells of the barracks: damp limestone, stale sweat, olive‑oil smoke from the torches that had burned all night, and the sour tang of the vinegar we drank to scrub yesterday’s dust from our throats. I rose, every scar on my back tightening like a stitch pulled too hard, and pressed my forehead to the wall—my morning ritual, the first part of it, anyway. A heartbeat’s communion with the stone to remind myself I was still flesh and not yet a ghost. Out in the corridor, wooden sandals slapped in uneven rhythms as slaves hurried toward the kitchen hearth. A pot of farro porridge hissed somewhere, and the scent of boiling grains mingled with garlic and pork fat. My stomach growled, but I waited. Three measured breaths, then I reached under the folded blanket on my cot for the amulet: a tiny copper figurine of Fortuna, battered smooth by years of handling. I kissed her feet—always the feet—then touched the figurine to each eyelid. The old Thracian who trained me claimed that Fortuna turned her wheel more gently for a man who acknowledged the mud before the crown. Superstition, yes, but so was half the Empire: augurs scanning birdflight, patricians reading burnt livers, emperors deified while their bodies were still warm. When I finally stepped into the courtyard, the sky was the color of a freshly honed blade, cloudless and hard. Forty of us gathered in loose ranks, some still yawning, others already rolling shoulders, the morning chill trapped in the steam of their breath. The sand underfoot clung to my soles, a reminder of where we would spend our lives—and most likely lose them. From across the yard I could hear the city already stirring. Mule carts trundled along the Vicus Tuscus, hawkers called out figs and honeyed nuts, and somewhere a woman scolded a child in shrill Oscan. Rome never truly slept; it only shifted its weight, like a beast dreaming of conquest. Our lanista, Cassius Pollio, appeared on the balcony above, toga as white as the marble he wished his lineage matched. He surveyed us the way a money‑changer weighs silver, lips pursed, brow furrowed as though the small arena beneath his house were the Senate floor. Rumor said Pollio had bought his way out of a provincial fraud charge by relinquishing a fortune to the emperor’s newest tax on fortunes. Now he filled his coffers by feeding men like me to the crowd’s appetite. Bread for the bellies, blood for the eyes—that was the bargain Rome struck with itself each morning. Training began with the wooden swords, the rudis. The thock of oak against oak echoed between stone walls, a percussion line under the cawing of rooftop crows. Sweat burned the cuts on my knuckles, but the ache was familiar, almost comforting. Across from me, Marcus the Syrian grinned through broken teeth, taunting in Greek, “Does the Gaul still dream of fields?” I answered with a low sweep meant to sting his shins. He dodged, laughing. We were friends, or as close as men can be when both know they might be ordered to kill each other before the month’s end. Between drills, Pollio read aloud the imperial bulletin. “His Excellency Trajan,” he began—stretching the name so we could taste its power—“has secured another victory across the Danube. The Senate proclaims one hundred days of celebration.” Cheers erupted; a hundred days meant a hundred games, and the more games, the higher the chance some of us would touch the wooden sword of freedom. Yet freedom bought with novelty was fragile. I had seen liberti begging outside the Subura, manumission tablets hanging from their necks like mockery. At midday we paused for the meal. Bowls of lentils, crusts of bread sprinkled with salt from Ostia’s flats. I ate seated on a low step, the sun now glaring from directly overhead. Its heat baked the sand, releasing the metallic scent of iron filings spilt during weapon repairs. A cicada droned somewhere near the barrack wall, its song a thin thread tying this day to every other long Roman summer. For a moment, memory slipped its leash: I saw green hills, felt the wet chill of a northern river on my calves, heard my sister’s voice carrying over barley stalks. The vision hurt more than any blade. But when Marcus plopped beside me, laughter in his eyes, the dream scattered like sparrows from a cat. We spent the afternoon oiling armor. The segmented plates of my lorica glinted, each ridge catching sun and reflecting it onto the wall in trembling patches. Ravens swooped overhead, drawn by the promise of scraps after tomorrow’s spectacles. I counted them—another piece of my ritual. If their number was even, Fortuna smiled. Seven today. I spat on the ground twice, then a third time—never fewer than three—and rubbed the saliva with my heel. Spit to bind, heel to hide; so taught the Thracian. Marcus rolled his eyes. “The gods are busy, friend,” he said. “They care little for spit.” I shrugged. “Then let them ignore me one more day.” Late afternoon brought a visit from the domina, Pollio’s wife, Livia Severina. She drifted through the yard in silk the hue of crushed pomegranates, attendant slaves shading her with fans of peacock feathers. Perfume of myrrh and rose preceded her, briefly conquering the stench of sweat. She paused to examine us like livestock, fingers brushing the ridges of my collarbone. “This one will entertain,” she told her steward, voice cool as well‑water. “Put him after the executions but before the chariot races; the crowd will be hungry for a closer kill.” My gut tightened—not fear of the fight, but of being slotted like a tile in someone else’s mosaic. I bowed my head, not trusting my voice. When she left, the yard exhaled. Marcus whispered, “Better her hand than the emperor’s.” He referred to the rumor sliding through Rome like grease: conspirators in the Senate planned to test Trajan’s patience. More games meant more taxes; more taxes meant more knives sharpened in shadows. The city felt ready to crack, though marble seemed unbreakable until it split. As the sun dipped toward the Aventine, we were finally dismissed. I returned to my cell, passing under the arch where previous champions’ names were carved. Most had dates beside them; a few were blank, the stone waiting for an end it knew would come. Inside, I knelt on the straw. Outside, the city began its evening chorus: tavern doors creaking open, lyres plucking from balconies, sandals scuffing mosaics. Somewhere near the Forum, senators would be reclining at banquets, debating provinces they would never see. I rinsed my hands in a wooden basin, water gone tepid. Then I opened the tiny leather pouch hanging from my belt and took out the second half of my ritual: a strip of cloth torn from my father’s cloak the day the legionaries dragged me from our farm. I wrapped it around my left wrist, knotting it twice—twice, never once—while murmuring a fragment of his favorite harvest hymn. The words were Gallic, foreign on Roman soil, but soft in my mouth. Night settled. Torches sputtered in the corridor, scenting the air with resin. I lay on the straw again, Fortune’s amulet cool against my chest, and listened to the distant rumble of the Colosseum being cleaned for tomorrow. Scrapers on stone, buckets sloshing water tinted pink from today’s blood. Rome would wake to find the arena pristine, as if violence were a dream washed away with dawn. I knew better. I carried every scream I had ever caused, every friend I might yet lose. But I also carried the weight of seven ravens and a strip of cloth and a goddess’s worn copper feet. For a man whose fate was decided by others, these small reliquiae were a rebellion—my own Senate, my own empire, ruled by the single law that I must survive one more day.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece effectively transports the reader to ancient Rome through the eyes of a Gallic gladiator. The author has crafted a rich sensory experience that immerses us in the sights, sounds, and smells of the ludus (gladiator training school) and the surrounding city. The piece excels in its sensory details: the "clang of the iron-barred gate," the "damp limestone, stale sweat, olive-oil smoke," and the "metallic scent of iron filings." These details create a vivid, textured world that feels authentic to the historical period. The author skillfully weaves in Roman cultural elements—from the farro porridge to the segmented lorica armor—without resorting to info-dumping. The protagonist is well-developed through his rituals, memories, and internal conflicts. His superstitions (kissing the Fortuna amulet, counting ravens) reveal his psychology and background, while his flashbacks to "green hills" and a "northern river" effectively establish his origins without heavy exposition. The character's complex relationship with his identity as both a Gaul and a gladiator creates meaningful tension. The prose is elegant without becoming overwrought. Metaphors like "the sky was the color of a freshly honed blade" and "Rome never truly slept; it only shifted its weight, like a beast dreaming of conquest" are evocative without feeling forced. The author maintains a consistent voice throughout—contemplative yet grounded in physical reality. The piece successfully incorporates the larger political context as requested, touching on Emperor Trajan's Danubian campaigns, senatorial conspiracies, and the social function of gladiatorial games ("Bread for the bellies, blood for the eyes"). These elements are integrated naturally through the protagonist's observations and conversations rather than through awkward exposition. The narrative flows well, moving through the gladiator's day with purpose. Each scene reveals something about the character, the setting, or the social dynamics at play. The piece feels like a slice of a larger story, as requested, with hints of past and future that extend beyond the immediate narrative. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. The relationship with Marcus could be developed further to heighten the emotional stakes of their potential future confrontation. Additionally, while the protagonist's internal life is rich, we get less sense of his specific fighting style or gladiatorial identity (whether he's a murmillo, retiarius, etc.), which might have added another layer of historical specificity. Overall, this is an accomplished piece of historical fiction that balances sensory immersion, character development, and historical context while maintaining narrative momentum.
